items.name: Ext.Array
items.text:
A set of useful static methods to deal with arrays; provide missing methods for
older browsers.

items.name: binarySearch
array
items.text: The array to search.

items.name: item
items.text: The item that you want to insert into the `array`.

items.name: begin
items.text: The first index in the `array` to consider.

items.name: end
items.text:
The index that marks the end of the range
to consider. The item at this index is *not* considered.

items.name: compareFn
items.text:
The comparison function that matches the sort
order of the `array`. The default `compareFn` compares items using less-than
and greater-than operators.

The index for the given item in the given array based on
the current sorters.

items.name: each
iterable
items.text:
The value to be iterated. If this
argument is not iterable, the callback function is called once.

items.name: fn
items.text: The callback function. If it returns `false`, the iteration stops and this method returns the current `index`. Returning undefined (i.e `return;`) will only exit the callback function and proceed with the next iteration in the loop.

items.name: item
items.text: The item at the current `index` in the passed `array`

items.name: index
items.text: The current `index` within the `array`

items.name: allItems
items.text: The `array` itself which was passed as the first argument

items.name: return
items.text: Return `false` to stop iteration.

items.name: scope
items.text: The scope (`this` reference) in which the specified function is executed.

items.name: reverse
items.text: Reverse the iteration order (loop from the end to the beginning).
See description for the `fn` parameter.

items.name: forEach
items.text: Iterates an array and invoke the given callback function for each item. Note that this will simply delegate to the native `Array.prototype.forEach` method if supported. It doesn't support stopping the iteration by returning `false` in the callback function like Ext.Array#each. However, performance could be much better in modern browsers comparing with Ext.Array#each

items.name: array
items.text: The array to iterate.

items.name: fn
items.text: The callback function.

items.name: item
items.text: The item at the current `index` in the passed `array`.

items.name: index
items.text: The current `index` within the `array`.

items.name: allItems
items.text: The `array` itself which was passed as the first argument.

items.name: scope
items.text:
(Optional) The execution scope (`this`) in which the
specified function is executed.

items.name: indexOf
items.text:
Get the index of the provided `item` in the given `array`, a supplement for the
missing arrayPrototype.indexOf in Internet Explorer.

items.name: array
items.text: The array to check.

items.name: item
items.text: The item to find.

items.name: from
items.text: (Optional) The index at which to begin the search.
The index of item in the array (or -1 if it is not found).

items.name: contains
items.text: Checks whether or not the given `array` contains the specified `item`.

items.name: array
items.text: The array to check.

items.name: item
items.text: The item to find.
`true` if the array contains the item, `false` otherwise.

items.name: toArray
iterable
items.text: the iterable object to be turned into a true Array.

items.name: start
items.text: a zero-based index that specifies the start of extraction.

items.name: end
items.text: a 1-based index that specifies the end of extraction.

items.name: pluck
items.text:
Plucks the value of a property from each item in the Array. Example:

    Ext.Array.pluck(Ext.query("p"), "className"); // [el1.className, el2.className, ..., elN.className]

items.name: array
items.text: The Array of items to pluck the value from.

items.name: propertyName
items.text: The property name to pluck from each element.
The value from each item in the Array.

items.name: map
items.text: Creates a new array with the results of calling a provided function on every element in this array.

items.name: fn
items.text: Callback function for each item.

items.name: item
items.text: Current item.

items.name: index
items.text: Index of the item.

items.name: array
items.text: The whole array that's being iterated.

items.name: scope
items.text: Callback function scope
results

items.name: every
items.text:
Executes the specified function for each array element until the function returns a falsy value.
If such an item is found, the function will return `false` immediately.
Otherwise, it will return `true`.

items.name: fn
items.text: Callback function for each item.

items.name: item
items.text: Current item.

items.name: index
items.text: Index of the item.

items.name: array
items.text: The whole array that's being iterated.

items.name: scope
items.text: Callback function scope.
`treu` if no false value is returned by the callback function.

items.name: some
items.text:
Executes the specified function for each array element until the function returns a truthy value.
If such an item is found, the function will return `true` immediately. Otherwise, it will return `false`.

items.name: fn
items.text: Callback function for each item.

items.name: item
items.text: Current item.

items.name: index
items.text: Index of the item.

items.name: array
items.text: The whole array that's being iterated.

items.name: scope
items.text: Callback function scope.
`true` if the callback function returns a truthy value.

items.name: equals
items.text: Shallow compares the contents of 2 arrays using strict equality.
`true` if the arrays are equal.

items.name: clean
items.text: Filter through an array and remove empty item as defined in Ext#isEmpty. See Ext.Array#filter
results

items.name: unique
items.text: Returns a new array with unique items.
results

items.name: filter
items.text:
Creates a new array with all of the elements of this array for which
the provided filtering function returns a truthy value.

items.name: fn
items.text: Callback function for each item.

items.name: item
items.text: Current item.

items.name: index
items.text: Index of the item.

items.name: array
items.text: The whole array that's being iterated.

items.name: scope
items.text: Callback function scope.
results

items.name: findBy
items.text:
Returns the first item in the array which elicits a truthy return value from the
passed selection function.

items.name: array
items.text: The array to search

items.name: fn
items.text: The selection function to execute for each item.

items.name: item
items.text: The array item.

items.name: index
items.text: The index of the array item.

items.name: scope
items.text: (optional) The scope (this reference) in which the function is executed. Defaults to the array

The first item in the array which returned true from the selection
function, or null if none was found.

items.name: from
items.text: Converts a value to an array if it's not already an array; returns: - An empty array if given value is undefined or null - Itself if given value is already an array - An array copy if given value is Ext#isIterable (arguments, NodeList and alike) - An array with one item which is the given value, otherwise

items.name: value
items.text: The value to convert to an array if it's not already is an array.

items.name: newReference
items.text: `true` to clone the given array and return a new reference if necessary.
array

items.name: remove
items.text: Removes the specified item from the array if it exists.

items.name: array
items.text: The array.

items.name: item
items.text: The item to remove.
The passed array.

items.name: removeAt
items.text: Removes item/s at the specified index.

items.name: array
items.text: The array.

items.name: index
items.text: The index of the item to be removed.

items.name: count
items.text: The number of items to be removed.
The passed array.

items.name: include
items.text: Push an item into the array only if the array doesn't contain it yet.

items.name: array
items.text: The array.

items.name: item
items.text: The item to include.

items.name: clone
items.text:
Clone a flat array without referencing the previous one. Note that this is different
from `Ext.clone` since it doesn't handle recursive cloning. It's simply a convenient, easy-to-remember method
for `Array.prototype.slice.call(array)`.

items.name: array
items.text: The array.
The clone array.

items.name: merge
items.text: Merge multiple arrays into one with unique items. Ext.Array#union is alias for Ext.Array#merge
merged

items.name: intersect
items.text: Merge multiple arrays into one with unique items that exist in all of the arrays.
intersect

items.name: difference
items.text: Perform a set difference A-B by subtracting all items in array B from array A.
difference

items.name: reduce
array
items.text: The array to process.

items.name: reduceFn
items.text: The reducing callback function.

items.name: previous
items.text: The previous value.

items.name: value
items.text: The current value.

items.name: index
items.text: The index in the array of the current `value`.

items.name: array
items.text: The array to being processed.

items.name: initialValue
items.text: The starting value.
The reduced value.

items.name: slice
items.text:
Returns a shallow copy of a part of an array. This is equivalent to the native
call `Array.prototype.slice.call(array, begin, end)`. This is often used when "array"
is "arguments" since the arguments object does not supply a slice method but can
be the context object to `Array.prototype.slice`.

items.name: array
items.text: The array (or arguments object).

items.name: begin
items.text:
The index at which to begin. Negative values are offsets from
the end of the array.

items.name: end

items.text: The copied piece of the array.

items.name: sort
items.text:
Sorts the elements of an Array in a stable manner (equivalently keyed values do not move relative to each other).
By default, this method sorts the elements alphabetically and ascending.
**Note:** This method modifies the passed array, in the same manner as the
native javascript Array.sort.

items.name: array
items.text: The array to sort.

items.name: sortFn
items.text: The comparison function.

items.name: a
items.text: The first item to compare.

items.name: b
items.text: The second item to compare.

items.name: return
items.text: `-1` if a < b, `1` if a > b, otherwise `0`.
The sorted array.

items.name: flatten
items.text: Recursively flattens into 1-d Array. Injects Arrays inline.

items.name: array
items.text: The array to flatten
The 1-d array.

items.name: min
items.text: Returns the minimum value in the Array.

items.name: array
items.text: The Array from which to select the minimum value.

items.name: comparisonFn
items.text:
(optional) a function to perform the comparison which determines minimization.
If omitted the "<" operator will be used.
__Note:__ gt = 1; eq = 0; lt = -1

items.name: min
items.text: Current minimum value.

items.name: item
items.text: The value to compare with the current minimum.
minValue The minimum value.

items.name: max
items.text: Returns the maximum value in the Array.

items.name: array
items.text: The Array from which to select the maximum value.

items.name: comparisonFn
items.text:
(optional) a function to perform the comparison which determines maximization.
If omitted the ">" operator will be used.
__Note:__ gt = 1; eq = 0; lt = -1

items.name: max
items.text: Current maximum value.

items.name: item
items.text: The value to compare with the current maximum.
maxValue The maximum value.

items.name: mean
items.text: Calculates the mean of all items in the array.

items.name: array
items.text: The Array to calculate the mean value of.
The mean.

items.name: sum
items.text: Calculates the sum of all items in the given array.

items.name: array
items.text: The Array to calculate the sum value of.
The sum.

items.name: toMap
array
items.text: The Array to create the map from.

items.name: getKey
items.text:
Name of the object property to use
as a key or a function to extract the key.

items.name: scope
items.text: Value of `this` inside callback specified for `getKey`.
The resulting map.

items.name: toValueMap
array
items.text: The Array to create the map from.

items.name: getKey
items.text:
Name of the object property to use
as a key or a function to extract the key.

items.name: scope
items.text:
Value of this inside callback. This parameter is only
passed when `getKey` is a function. If `getKey` is not a function, the 3rd
argument is `arrayify`.

items.name: arrayify
items.text:
Pass `1` to create arrays for all map entries
or `2` to create arrays for map entries that have 2 or more items with the
same key. This only applies when `getKey` is specified. By default the map will
hold the last entry with a given key.
The resulting map.

items.name: erase
items.text:
Removes items from an array. This is functionally equivalent to the splice method
of Array, but works around bugs in IE8's splice method and does not copy the
removed elements in order to return them (because very often they are ignored).

items.name: array
items.text: The Array on which to replace.

items.name: index
items.text: The index in the array at which to operate.

items.name: removeCount
items.text: The number of items to remove at index.
The array passed.

items.name: insert
items.text: Inserts items in to an array.

items.name: array
items.text: The Array in which to insert.

items.name: index
items.text: The index in the array at which to operate.

items.name: items
items.text: The array of items to insert at index.
The array passed.

items.name: replace
items.text:
Replaces items in an array. This is functionally equivalent to the splice method
of Array, but works around bugs in IE8's splice method and is often more convenient
to call because it accepts an array of items to insert rather than use a variadic
argument list.

items.name: array
items.text: The Array on which to replace.

items.name: index
items.text: The index in the array at which to operate.

items.name: removeCount
items.text: The number of items to remove at index (can be 0).

items.name: insert
items.text: (optional) An array of items to insert at index.
The array passed.

items.name: splice
items.text:
Replaces items in an array. This is equivalent to the splice method of Array, but
works around bugs in IE8's splice method. The signature is exactly the same as the
splice method except that the array is the first argument. All arguments following
removeCount are inserted in the array at index.

items.name: array
items.text: The Array on which to replace.

items.name: index
items.text: The index in the array at which to operate.

items.name: removeCount
items.text: The number of items to remove at index (can be 0).

items.name: elements
items.text:
The elements to add to the array. If you don't specify
any elements, splice simply removes elements from the array.
An array containing the removed items.

items.name: push
items.text:
Pushes new items onto the end of an Array.

Passed parameters may be single items, or arrays of items. If an Array is found in the argument list, all its
elements are pushed into the end of the target Array.

items.name: target
items.text: The Array onto which to push new items

items.name: elements
items.text:
The elements to add to the array. Each parameter may
be an Array, in which case all the elements of that Array will be pushed into the end of the
destination Array.
An array containing all the new items push onto the end.

items.name: numericSortFn
items.text:
A function used to sort an array by numeric value. By default, javascript array values
are coerced to strings when sorting, which can be problematic when using numeric values. To
ensure that the values are sorted numerically, this method can be passed to the sort method:

    Ext.Array.sort(myArray, Ext.Array.numericSortFn);
